question: [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Association/Association_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertIsAuthorizedProposer()] [Authorization Bypass] Can an attacker bypass proposer authorization by exploiting the null organization check before whitelist validation, allowing proposal creation with a crafted organization address that returns null but doesn't trigger the assertion? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Association/Association_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertIsAuthorizedProposer()] [Race Condition] If ProposerWhiteList is modified between the assertion check and actual proposal creation, can an attacker create proposals after being removed from the whitelist, violating the authorization invariant? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Association/Association_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertIsAuthorizedProposer()] [DOS Attack] Can an attacker cause DOS by creating an organization with an extremely large ProposerWhiteList (e.g., millions of addresses), making the Contains() check gas-exhaustive for legitimate proposers? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Association/Association_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertIsAuthorizedProposer()] [Logic Error] Does the Contains() method perform case-sensitive or case-insensitive address comparison, potentially allowing bypass through address case manipulation? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Association/Association_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertIsAuthorizedProposer()] [Data Integrity] If State.Organizations returns a corrupted or partially initialized organization object (non-null but with null ProposerWhiteList), can this cause a null reference exception or bypass the whitelist check? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Association/Association_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertIsAuthorizedOrganizationMember()] [Authorization Bypass] Can an attacker vote on proposals by exploiting organizations with empty OrganizationMemberList that still pass this check through Contains() returning false but not throwing? (High)
